thread.title: Dog owner flashes BUM after walking free despite rottweiler savaging girl, 5
thread.title_full: Dog owner flashes BUM after walking free despite rottweiler savaging girl, 5

title: Dog owner flashes BUM after walking free despite rottweiler savaging girl, 5
text:
NCJ MEDIA FLASHER: Natalie Reid got her bum out as she was leaving court 
Natalie Reid, 29, saw her rottweiler Bruce jump up a garden wall and sink its teeth into the five-year-old child’s arm. 
The girl was reportedly left “screaming in pain and terror” when the dog dragged the youngster towards the wall. 
South East Northumberland Magistrates’ Court heard the attack only came to an end when the child’s horrified mother managed to wrench the animal off. 
The girl was left with bruising and needed medical attention and a course of antibiotics after the incident in Eastgate, Ashington. 
But Reid, who is also known as McMillan, has walked away with a fine of just £220 after pleading guilty to having a dog that was dangerously out of control and caused injury. GRAPHIC CONTENT: Worst cases of animal cruelty Monday, 28th November 2016 WARNING GRAPHIC CONTENT: As part of our new 'STOP THE CRUELTY' campaign we take a look at some of the most horrific cases animal cruelty. 1 / 29 PA Handout photo issued by the Orangutan Foundation of Aan, a critically-endangered orangutan who was blinded after being shot more than 100 times with an air rifle. Aan is to undergo an operation that could restore her sight. “It looks as though the dog has snapped the lead” Graham Crouth, mitigating 
Prosecuting, Anna Barker told the court the girl was attacked when she was walking home with her mum on November 18 last year. 
She said: “The girl was walking along the road when they approached the defendant's address and a rottweiler jumped up and almost over a low, brick wall and took hold of the girl by the right arm. 
"She was dragged towards the wall and was screaming in pain and terror. 
"Her mother and her friend managed to separate her daughter and the dog and they managed to get away. 
"The dog was restrained by a tether but had managed to get up and onto the pavement.” 
The court heard Reid later went to the family’s home and apologised, bringing gifts for the girl. 
Graham Crouth, mitigating, said Reid had never had any issues with the dog before. 
He said: "The dog is usually in the back yard but Miss Reid was getting some work done there, so it was outside the front of the house. 
"It's usually tethered by a chain but, on this occasion, it was tethered by a lead. It looks as though the dog has snapped the lead. 
"She has become aware very, very quickly about the incident and recovers the dog and puts it in the house." 
Magistrates ordered that Bruce must be muzzled and kept on a lead in public, as well as securely tied up in the garden. 
Reid was also ordered to pay £20 compensation and £40 costs. Related articles
